awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will be the development of a new strategy for patterning polymers on the microscale.  Specifically, this project will develop a high-resolution volumetric 3D printer. This printer will generate objects in high performance materials that feature no accompanying support structures, and minimal artifacts such as layering from the printing process. This project will achieve printing at the focal point of a laser beam. Because this process has substantially reduced power requirements, printing can be achieved much faster and a a significantly reduced cost. This technology will support rapid prototyping of ultrahigh resolution parts or creation of microelectromechanical systems and will enable widespread use. 

This project will build a volumetric 3D printer based on photon upconversion nanocapsules. These nanocapsules contain a liquid core of molecules that undergo triplet-triplet annihilation to convert red photons to blue photons with a quadratic power dependence. When paired with an appropriate photopolymerization scheme that is activated by blue light but transparent to red light, these nanocapsules can be used to drive polymerization exclusively at the focal point of a red laser. The development of larger anti-stokes shifts for the upconversion process, and the enhancement of the upconversion efficiency will allow for rapid printing. Work optimizing upconversion wavelengths and efficiencies will be achieved using photoluminescence spectroscopy. The development of multiplexed optical schemes will further enhance the printing speed. Beam profiling will be performed to determine the success of light-shaping approaches. Functionalization of the nanocapsules will allow them to be made compatible with a broad range of 3D printing resins. Development of resins especially suited for this style of 3D printing will further differentiate this technology from existing approaches to 3D printing.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

inst.inst_street_address: 21 REV NAZARENO PROPERZI WAY STE N

por.por_cntn:
In this project we demonstrated the feasibility of a volumetric 3D printing solution, based on novel upconversion nanomaterials, capable of fabricating high-resolution parts without supports or layers in a high-performance resin.  The upconversion materials are used to convert higher wavelength laser light (e.g., red) to lower wavelength light (e.g., blue) at the focal point of the laser beam, and when included in a resin that solidifies when exposed to the upconverted lower wavelength light, can achieve 3D printing in a volume of resin.  Instead of an interfacial process that suffers from drawbacks, such as lines between layers, and need for support structures on parts, our process prints a 3D object in a volume of a photopolymer including upconverting nanocapsules that avoids such drawbacks. Our work included development of upconversion materials in the form of nanocapsules with improved performance, new high-performance resins, and improved upconversion printing resins.  In this project, we developed upconverting nanocapsules with improved quantum yield and surface chemistry to enable faster 3D printing. Our resin work included development of new resins with improved thermal properties for use in high temperature applications and improved upconversion printing resin formulations. We also developed printers that could address these resins with improved speed and resolution relative to our earlier efforts. Finally, we spent time printing with upconversion resins to determine under what conditions they could yield the best prints. This work led to development of optimized print parameters that could yield better quality prints in relatively short amounts of time. 

 


Last Modified: 03/01/2022
Modified by: Samuel N Sanders
por.por_txt_cntn:
In this project we demonstrated the feasibility of a volumetric 3D printing solution, based on novel upconversion nanomaterials, capable of fabricating high-resolution parts without supports or layers in a high-performance resin.  The upconversion materials are used to convert higher wavelength laser light (e.g., red) to lower wavelength light (e.g., blue) at the focal point of the laser beam, and when included in a resin that solidifies when exposed to the upconverted lower wavelength light, can achieve 3D printing in a volume of resin.  Instead of an interfacial process that suffers from drawbacks, such as lines between layers, and need for support structures on parts, our process prints a 3D object in a volume of a photopolymer including upconverting nanocapsules that avoids such drawbacks. Our work included development of upconversion materials in the form of nanocapsules with improved performance, new high-performance resins, and improved upconversion printing resins.  In this project, we developed upconverting nanocapsules with improved quantum yield and surface chemistry to enable faster 3D printing. Our resin work included development of new resins with improved thermal properties for use in high temperature applications and improved upconversion printing resin formulations. We also developed printers that could address these resins with improved speed and resolution relative to our earlier efforts. Finally, we spent time printing with upconversion resins to determine under what conditions they could yield the best prints. This work led to development of optimized print parameters that could yield better quality prints in relatively short amounts of time.
